relationships.evidence_text: Nicolette Han Niamen, the author of Defending Beef.

relationships.relationship: is a writer, attorney, and livestock rancher
relationships.evidence_text: Nicolette Han Niamen is a writer, attorney, and livestock rancher.
She authored the book Defending Beef as well as the book, Righteous Pork Chop.
has written numerous essays for the New York Times.
has written numerous essays for the Wall Street Journal.
has written numerous essays for the Los Angeles Times.
has also written for the Atlantic.
has also written for the San Francisco Chronicle.
has also written for the Earth Island Journal.
Nicolette is a frequent speaker at National and International conferences.
was one of just 23 speakers from around the world at the Nobel Week Dialogue in 2016 in Stockholm, Sweden.
has appeared on the PBS News Hour.
has appeared on the Dr. Oz Show.
has appeared in numerous films and documentaries, including eating animals, as well as sustainable.
her work has been featured in Time.
her work has been featured in O Magazine.
her work has been featured in the Guardian.
she was senior attorney for the Environmental Organization Waterkeeper.
she focused on animal agriculture.
before that was an Environmental Lawyer for National Wildlife Federation.
Nicolette served two terms on the City Commission for Kalamazoo, Michigan.
today, she lives in Northern California.
with her two sons and her husband, Bill Niamen.
founder of the Natural Meat Companies, Niamen Ranch and BN Ranch.

a lot of people think just by eating soy or just by eating, you know, potatoes, again, you're going to get enough protein.
there's a whole narrative out there that we eat too much protein in the industrialized world.
it kind of goes back to that evolutionary argument.
as Fred Provenza shows in his study in his books.
having an animal in a healthful environment... is really important to producing food that is supportive of vibrant health over the long term.
if you are eating foods that are from an industrial system, especially processed foods.
